title: U.S. Supreme Court Will Decide if Chemical Manufacturers Can Be Sued for Failure to Disclose Pesticide Hazards - Beyond Pesticides Daily News Blog
description: (Beyond Pesticides, January 17, 2026) The public‚Äôs right to sue chemical manufacturers that do not warn of product hazards will be up for review by the U.S. Supreme Court later this year, the justices decided Friday. Bayer/Monsanto is challenging billions of dollars in jury verdicts, which affirm longstanding jurisprudence that holds manufacturers responsible for disclosing hazards even when not required to do so by regulatory authorities. In the case being challenged, Durnell, John L. v. Monsanto, the injured party successfully argued that a chemical manufacturer has a duty to warn of potential hazards on their product label even though the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) does not require the warning. The failure-to-warn in the Durnell case resulted in a jury verdict of $1.2 billion and the total number of jury verdicts and settlements on similar cases may amount to over $10 billion in liability if the Supreme Court upholds the lower courts and hundreds of thousands of other plaintiffs with the same claim. The cases involve exposure to the weed killer glyphosate (RoundupTM, which is the most widely used herbicide in the U.S. and worldwide, has been classified as posing a possible risk of cancer by the International Agency for […]

name: Clean Air & Water
title: U.S. - ⭐EPA Employee Spotlight⭐   Meet Chelsea Hidalgo, a Toxicologist and Risk Assessor for U.S. EPA South Central Region's Superfund and Emergency Management Division.  Over her six years at the agency, Chelsea has become a valued team member, known for her strong communication skills, technical expertise and collaborative approach. Chelsea was invited to deliver risk assessment and risk communication trainings at the regional and national levels, as well as to state partners.   Last year, she completed the Region 6 Leadership Career Development Program, a program for staff to learn leadership skills, handle difficult situations, and connect with other employees in meaningful ways. Chelsea is known for her friendly and energetic personality, and outside of work you can find her cheering on the Dallas Stars and birdwatching on local hikes.   Thank you for making a difference at EPA and beyond! | Facebook

description:
Conservation groups filed a lawsuit today challenging the Environmental Protection Agency’s approval of isocycloseram, a “forever chemical” insecticide that falls into the class of highly persistent PFAS, or per- or polyfluoroalkyl substances.

The insecticide was approved for use on golf courses, lawns and a host of food crops, including apples, oranges, lettuce, spinach, tomatoes, broccoli, bell peppers, cucumbers, peaches, almonds, wheat and oats.

title: US EPA Air Quality data, 1972-1988
description: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency air pollution monitoring data from 1972 through 1988 consist of raw, monitor-level observations for sulfur dioxide (SO₂), total suspended particulates (TSP), nitrogen dioxide (NO₂), ozone (O₃), and carbon monoxide (CO), obtained directly from the EPA. SO₂ measurements typically reflect sample durations of about one hour, while other pollutants are reported according to contemporaneous EPA monitoring practices, with substantial variation in sampling frequency and spatial coverage across pollutants and years. SO₂ has the broadest and most consistent coverage, with thousands of monitors operating in over 1,000 counties, whereas TSP is measured less frequently, O₃ data are largely unavailable prior to 1980, NO₂ coverage declines by the late 1980s, and CO data become widely available starting in the mid-1970s.  The provided .do file serves as an example for how to process the provided datasets into a daily monitor-level dataset.
